text: Okay awesome! Really glad you have skills in both Cinema 4D and Maya, that's very useful. So at the moment, you're interested in doing an animation internship ideally I assume? Would you also consider internships in other areas of the animation pipeline?
I've had a look at your website, I think it's really great that you've kept it very simple and clean to let the work speak for itself

I think what we'll mostly be discussing here is 2 different areas of advice to help you improve. 1. Employability advice, so your showreel, portfolio website, CV etc is in the best place it can be to apply for internships. and 2. Technical animation advice, as I think if Character Animation is what you're most interested in and where you want to be moving forward, that's what they'd need to see much more of in the showreel.
Just some first impressions for the website and showreel to get started with:

Website: Nice, clean and simple structure is great. I think your homepage needs to be more obvious that you are an animator and that's what you want to do. Instead of an illustration as your homepage, which I appreciate looks really nice but isn't super relevant to how you want to brand yourself, having a link to your showreel there would be best. I first looked at the website on my phone, and the links at the bottom for animation/illustration etc aren't immediately obvious that that's where those projects are, so I didn't know where any animation was when I looked at it on that platform. It's only when on my laptop I was able to see where the animation was so bare that in mind. Make it as easy as possible for people to find the thing you want them to look at!
Also, make the showreel bigger on the animation website page - it's the most important bit!

Showreel: I definitely get the vibe with this that nearly every project you've worked on in a 3D software is in some capacity on this reel - and I totally get that. I definitely understand the need to want to fill up the time, and that you don't have lots of shots from hundreds of episodes or minutes of a feature film to put in there! But at the moment I don't think all of it is relevant, and recruiters and animation directors would much rather see 30 seconds of a strong, high-quality animation than a 1min 30 of mixed.
To start with I would keep these shots: Teal box jumping around with the spray can, teal box and looking side to side. Teal box when the lightening strikes. Ball with legs jumping over the cogs.

The others, I think - animation poses for the characters is a really wonderful exercise to keep practicing with (and it's something we'll follow up on later down the line), but it's not a showreel piece. Directors would know you can pose a character based on the lovely poses within your animation, having separate static poses for characters aren't needed. The rest are either very abstract, exercises that are good for practicing (but are not showreel pieces, and we'll also speak about the differences between these later), or aren't relevant to the level of animation you're looking to showcase. Above all I think we need some strong character pieces in there.
Some materials I think would be super useful for you to look at as well:

<https://www.animscrawl.com/blog> - A blog written by one of our Animation Directors at Blue Zoo. He has a topic on there called 'Reel talk' with lots of great advice for how to set up a showreel. In particular I think this one is very useful, <https://www.animscrawl.com/blog/reel-talk-what-to-put-in-a-reel>

<https://animdojo.com/> - This is where I learned to animate properly. It's an online school that costs Â£15 GBP a month (about 20 dollars) and teaches you what a professional animators workflow looks like, and how to do it _fast._ There's also live streams on there with people from Disney, Dreamworks, Sony, Framestore, Blue Zoo and Axis Animation, where you can be taught by them or see their working process as they animate live. Above all, if you're interested in that resource, there's a set of videos *you need to watch* when you first sign up called The Animators Checklist. These will help beyond anything else when it comes to understanding character animation and using a proper animation workflow.

attachments.title: AnimDojo: The online animation gym.
attachments.text: An affordable of improving your CG character animation skills.

text: If you're not in a position to afford a monthly subscription (which I totally get) then that's totally fine, we look into other things. But it doesn't have to be a years subscription, it is available to sign up for a month, watch the videos, and then cancel the following month, but if that doesn't work then not a problem.
I know that's a lot of information to read, apologies for that! But hopefully, that's a good place to get started!
